title: 104_hr851
content: The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" establishes a project for rural telemedicine. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" establishes up to 10 pilot projects to study the use of rural health care provider telemedicine networks for physician consultative services under Medicare in rural areas. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" allows multispecialty tertiary care providers to form networks for patient referral, joint communications, and transportation in rural or underserved areas designated by the Secretary. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" allows multispecialty tertiary care providers to form networks for patient referral, joint communications, and transportation in rural or underserved areas designated by the Secretary. Medicare payment for participants is addressed in Section 3. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" allows for payments from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for physicians' services in rural areas, even if the provider is not physically present. The Secretary will establish a methodology for determining the amount of payments based on available funds. The Secretary will establish a methodology for determining payments under subsection (a), including payment for signal transmission facilities for physician consultative services. Payments under subsection (a) can be made for any service without requiring the provider to be a physician. SEC. 4. ELIGIBILITY OF NETWORKS. Networks eligible for pilot project if they submit required application and information to the Secretary. Rural area defined as per Social Security Act. SEC. 5. CRITERIA FOR SELECTING PARTICIPANTS. SEC. 5. CRITERIA FOR SELECTING PARTICIPANTS. Priority given to networks facilitating patient-specialist consultations with detailed data transmission. Existing networks can participate. SEC. 6. REPORTS. The Secretary must submit an interim report to Congress within 24 months of making payments for services under a pilot project, detailing the projects and networks involved, expenses, and number of patients served. A final report must be submitted within 1 year after project termination, analyzing cost-effectiveness, success in providing specialist consultations in rural areas, and impact on patient access to higher quality care. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 24 months of pilot project payments, detailing projects, expenses, and patients served. The report must also include an analysis of cost-effectiveness, success in providing specialist consultations in rural areas, and impact on patient access to higher quality care. Additionally, the report should contain recommendations for changes in the Medicare program related to telemedicine, including cost estimates. Authorization of appropriations from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for a total of $51,000,000 for a demonstration project under this Act, with up to $1,000,000 allocated for administrative purposes, including report submissions.
